Reviews.Title: “Good enough”
Reviews.Author: freedomyears
Reviews.Content: This is by no means in the centre of Barcelona, however it is fairly close to the metro and bus services. Two stops from Espanya and from there you can easily change to most other lines. Had a slight struggle finding it, keep Ikea on your right, cross over at the round about, it will be the second on the left, a main street called Botanica which is well sign posted, Keep walking left and you will see it. To get to metro walk back down and keep Ikea on your left! Room was spacious and clean, staff were pleasant enough, bar one snappy female receptionist. Most speak good English. We didn't eat in the area, however we did see all the eating areas in Gran Via 2 which have been mentioned in previous posts which all looked nice. We bought an unlimited 4 day travel pass (can use it on metro, bus train etc etc) which was 27 euros, we felt a bit ripped off as we were trying to buy another ticket, however we did take full advantage of it and at the end it was a pretty good deal. I'm a bit wary of buses so we took the metro and train back out to the airport, was easy and quick to do - check the time table for the train, they aren't as frequent as the metro. I would return again, but on for the same price (30 euros a night) Anymore and i would try and find something more central. Older guests, or those with an injury/disability may want to avoid this as there is some walking involved, and we were less likely to return during the day for a rest due to it location. Perfect for young people of a quick city break.

Reviews.Title: “very bad!!!!”
Reviews.Author: oren n
Reviews.Content: after we stay 4 nighats the transport from the hotel was at 22.00 pm and the check out at 10.00 them told us to find another place to keep our stuff.to the hotel not have any room to keep the suitcases. we left the hotel at 10.00 am with all our stuff at the metro far from the hotel in the central station,and in the night we back to central station to take again all the stuff and reback to the hotel for the transport to the airport!! bad bad bad!!!

Reviews.Title: “Glorified youth hostel in terrible location”
Reviews.Author: HFoz
Reviews.Content: I have to admit that this was a bad choice on my part. If you have paid 20 euro a night and you are travelling on a budget I don't suppose this would be too bad. However the location is the biggest issue. We took taxis everywhere so by the time you have paid that you may as well stay centrally. So the Travelodge was as you would expect, very clean I have to say. The bed was really uncomfortable. A mattress as thick as a napkin! It was rock hard. Service was pleasant and helpful. I guess the biggest problem was that we were there for Mobile World Congress so we paid 350 euro for two nights, totally sickening, and for that price you feel mugged off! Anyway if you know what to expect from a Travelodge - a glorified hostel - then this won't offer any nasty surprises but it won't offer any nice ones either! Be warned re the location, especially if you are a lone traveller or girls, walking around in those parts would not be recommended.

Reviews.Title: “value for money base to explore...”
Reviews.Author: kimmoorin
Reviews.Content: visited this hotel as a group of 13 friends and family for a pre-xmas break. this was my 2nd visit to the hotel, and found it wasnt as good as last time (approx 3 years ago). staff did not know which bus we should take to the city centre and the food vending machine in reception was empty. if its empty then dont show it, hide it! we avoided breakfast after reading reviews on here but the BP garage next door does fab croissants and pastries from about 0900, can get takeaway coffee too for 1 euro. we tended to travel in to the city via train (buy a T10 travel card....10 journies for 8 euros...one card can be swiped twice if there are 2 of you and only there for a couple of days) and taxi back to the hotel (approx 14 euros from placa catalunya). be very wary of scams on las ramblas where you guess which cup has the item under it...saw several people hand over money then the guys just took the money and ran! no game! we were lucky enough to book the hotel during the travelodge sale and paid 10 euros per room per night for 6 rooms! given that, it doesnt seem right to complain and would still stay there again! bear in mind there are no restaurants near the hotel so we ate out before returning each day.

Reviews.Title: “Good cheap stay”
Reviews.Author: MrsTH_9
Reviews.Content: We stayed just 1 night while we went to see Les Mis in Barcelona. It was a nice, clean, standard Travelodge. The staff were helpful and spoke good english. The room was clean and the bathroom was fine. We only paid 35 euros which is so good for Baecelona. It is rather out of the way but the parking is free. We ate at Ikea as we were visiting there anyway . The first 30 mins of wi-fi were free...take note UK travelodges!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Good location and price”
Reviews.Author: tigru8haiduc
Reviews.Content: We got it for a very good deal. Stay 4 and pay 3 nights rooms only. It mught seem a bit out of the way location wise, but it is a good base for exploring Barcelona. The suburban rail station is a few minutes away. The worst thing was that we got to Barcelona late during a rainy night, It was a pain finding it so make sure you've got the directions right.

Reviews.Title: “Pleasant stay.”
Reviews.Author: djstu77
Reviews.Content: Stayed 1 night here at the beginning of November. Very clean rooms and good shower. Free parking which was good. Wifi worked in the bar for 20 minutes then you had to pay, so a bit tight there. Reception staff were helpful and pleasant. The address on the web site did not help in finding the hotel and better directions would have helped. Overall if you are a few nights in Barcelona and want a cheap hotel then this is it.

Reviews.Title: “welcoming and helpfull receptionists”
Reviews.Author: Chebat
Reviews.Content: Excellent choice when you are attending the fair just minutes walking distance...Clean and comfortable room. welcoming and very helpfull receptionists.It is a little bit far from central Barcelona but still you find a train station nearby.

Reviews.Title: “Passionate Stay”
Reviews.Author: pattipatel
Reviews.Content: We had a lovely stay, very reasonable cost, (On offer). One downside was the air con. We were not able to alter it in our room . the switch was disabled, We had to keep ringing the reception staff and ask them to alter it!! Not good. We found we had to walk just for ten minues to get to the station. There was a bus stop a minutes walk from the Travelodge. I would stay there again. Breakfast bar on site, but didn't use it. We found the IKEA store good for gravelux at lunchtime. (Please note,; IKEA UK family cards , for free tea and coffee , are not honoured in this store! Why? There was a Chinese buffet at the Gran Via shopping centre which was good, cheap and soo close to the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect for what we wanted”
Reviews.Author: Alexbrearley
Reviews.Content: Myself and my partner stayed here for 3 nights in October and it was ideal for us. We bought a travel card for 21 euros from the airport and that gave us travel on the buses, metro and trams for 4 days, excellent value for money! We were going to book a transfer from the airport for 80 euros but decided to 'wing' it on the no. 46 bus, and i'm glad we did! We did get a little disorientated finding the hotel, get off at Ikea then walk up passed the frontage then turn down the side, got over the traffic island, keep walking and at the next junction look left and you should see the hotel, it is about a 5 min walk from the bus stop. Other travellers were right about the breakfasts there, we didnt bother at 7.50 it was pricey, we found the local coffee shops with their delicious pastries were far cheaper, we paid less than 5 euros for both of us for lovely coffee and pastries. Despite previous visitors saying it is very expensive we didnt think and found a lovely tapas bar just off the La Ramblas which was about 25 euros including drinks, we also found an all you can eat buffet place at the top of La Ramblas which was only 9.50 a head including a drink, this was excellent value for money and we were stuffed! We went on a 30min boat trip around the harbour, well worth it, it was lovely, that was only 6.50 so again reasonably priced. The hotel itself we have to say was very clean and tidy, most of the staff we found were pleasant and helpful, it was only one male member of staff who just ignored us! Once we'd found our feet we made good use of the bus service and it was really easy and quick to get around, it was only 10 mins to get into the city centre, we would definitely use this hotel again, just what you expect from Travellodge, cheap rooms that are clean and purposeful.

Reviews.Title: “Not close to anything”
Reviews.Author: chanchan_11
Reviews.Content: The only reason we stayed at this hotel was it was close to the Sant Jordi stadium since we were going to Sensation and it was cheaper then the rest. This hotel is in a industrial area which it was quiet. The hotel room was nice and big (bed was not too comfortable). And the hotel staff was nice, friendly, and helpful. However, it was so hard to find this hotel and when I asked locals they didn't know either. It is pretty far from the city of Barcelona. There are no restaurants nearby, we had to always take the metro to find a place to eat. And the metro was not close to the hotel either, it was maybe like a 10-15 minute walk. The neighborhood was ok but I wouldn't want to stay out too late since from the metro to the hotel there wasn't too much walk lights. They only provide you with 30 minutes of free wifi a day.

Reviews.Title: “Standard Travelodge but not a good area”
Reviews.Author: s_granton
Reviews.Content: I stayed here with my wife and 3 kids in late August for 7 nights in a family room. We arrived at Barcelona airport and jumped in an airport taxi only to find out that the Taxi driver didn't know where the hotel was. I had Google Maps Navigation on my phone and used it to direct the driver. However, on arrival at the address there was no hotel. We had to phone the hotel and the receptionist directed the driver further down the road to where the hotel was (it is near a BP garage behind the FIRA exhibition centre). The hotel is a standard Travelodge (if you are familiar with them from the UK) fairly basic but generally clean and cheap and everything was as expected there. We'd even phoned ahead to see if they had cots for babies and they said they only had 2 but would put one in the room for us - which they did without further prompting. The main area of the ground floor is taken up with tables mainly used for breakfast and not the sort you'd want to sit and relax in so consequently there were never many people in the lobby area. This contributed to the hotel having an empty feel, which was compounded by the fact that the bar closed relatively early each night. The family room we had was large and big enough for the double bed, sofa bed, and a babies travel cot. It was air conditioned and a welcome relief from the heat of the day (and night). The main downside of this hotel is it's location. It's situated between the airport and the main city area in an industrial part of town near the docks. It is also away from the main bus routes. It is surrounded by the large FIRA exhibition centre to the front and industrial units on other sides which mean the general area is pretty empty of people outside of work hours and at the weekends. We walked with the kids to a Carrefour and large shopping centre "Gran Via 2" the other side of the exhibition centre which had plenty of bars and restaurants. However, the walk back was pretty scary at night in the dark as there was no-one around. One night we started to be followed by two homeless people so my wife and kids ran ahead while I kept back to discourage any attempt to mug us! After that we started to use the buses a lot. There are bus stops near the hotel though to get into the centre of Barcelona you need to change near Gran Via and that can be costly. We managed to get tickets with 10 trips on them as it was cheaper than paying each trip. Be careful however, as the buses back to the hotel stop around 10pm and one night we missed the last bus. Rather than walk back (after previous experiences) we jumped in a taxi and got back safely. However the taxi driver advised that the hotel was in an area renowned for drugs and homeless people. Of course Barcelona itself was fantastic and the kids enjoyed seeing all the sights. However, on balance I don't think we'll be using this hotel again.

Reviews.Title: “stay at the downtown”
Reviews.Author: ugurkoksal
Reviews.Content: cheap hotel but far from downtown. first you must walk 15 min to train station , get the train for 2 station, then change for metro. poor breakfast slipshod rooms. try to find another hotel nearest downtown.

Reviews.Title: “clean and nice but in the middle of nowhere!”
Reviews.Author: londonColly
Reviews.Content: Just came back from Barcelona after spending 4 nights at the Travelodge hotel. In overall we are quite satisfied with our stay apart from two things: wifi connection did not work for the first 2 days, hotel is located in the middle of nowhere (we called it), its about 15 mins walk to the nearest tube station (Fira Europa), to get to the centre you need to get a train to Placa Espanya and then a metro. There are no shops, pubs or bars around, so you better do all your food shopping in Carrefour located near the tube station. There is also a massive shopping centre where you can buy everything you want and a few restaurants. All members of staff were nice, friendly, spoke good english and helped us with everything we needed, Rooms were cleaned everyday, we also got our towels changed, air con worked perfectly (we had to switch it off at night as it got too cold). Comparing it to the british travelodge I must say that the standard is a bit lower, but for the price we paid in the high season we could not expect anything else. Just because of the location and the time we spent on travelling into the town I dont think I would choose this hotel again. For those looking for a cheap and nice accommodation the hotel should be great.

Reviews.Title: “Basic, but adiquite”
Reviews.Author: travelbug2145
Reviews.Content: If you do use this hotel, be aware that on the 2nd floor, smoking is permited. The Metro is in easy walking distance to get into Barcelona. The garage next door is open till 10pm (stock up on your beers and snacks) A, T.10 Ticket is great value as you are able to use a public transport..(if you use 1,2,3,or,4 modes of transport within 1hr 15mins) it is classed as 1 journey. I would advise not to have a breackfast or evening meal, Ikea is just up the road for a quick bite to eat before getting into Barcelona, GREAT VALUE. The hotel is very busy, (the doors slam and bang on a regular basis, not very sound proof )

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel and good location for travellers with a car”
Reviews.Author: Olgash6
Reviews.Content: excellent hotel and friendly staff. Warmly recommend for those who travel by car. The only negative - the lack of storage space for luggage

Reviews.Title: “Cheap at a price”
Reviews.Author: colonelcrow
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 3 nights in a hot Catalonian July and, although we were pleased the air conditioning was excellent, were less pleased at the 10/15 minute walk from Europa Fira after a day trekking around the city. The hotel is dead cheap but, as the other reviews state, is 5 minutes on the metro to Espanyol, 5 on the metro to Europa Fira and then a 15 minute walk through a quiet conference centre and trading estate. There is certainly nothing 'dodgy' about the area - the only people about are other guests or people filling up with petrol. If you want cheap and can bare a wee walk in the morning/evening, then this is a good option.

Reviews.Title: “Good for what it is”
Reviews.Author: SBnHV
Reviews.Content: This is not a great hotel that you'd enjoy spending your day in - it is a good hotel to serve as a base from which to see the city or to go to the conference centre nearby. I only stayed here 2 nights for a conference in town. Location was picked as it was between airport and city (arrived very late and had to leave very early). Very basic hotel, but room was simple, clean and had everything I needed. Foyer looked a bit depressing though (matched the industrial area it is located in) and I would not want to have lunch or dinner here. Number of buses into city or to airport walking distance from hotel. Decent price for what you get.

Reviews.Title: “Below Par”
Reviews.Author: oleadam
Reviews.Content: We booked this hotel as it fitted our budget. In some ways it was a typical Travelodge. Cheap and clean. The rooms were very tidy and the staff were very helpful. But if Im honest it was still below what we expected because of the following reasons : the air con was "centrally controlled", so could not be adjusted, which meant although our room was hot it was freezing with the air con on and sleeping with the window open meant we were awoken by the garage opening next door at around 6am. There was no English TV channels. After a long day of travelling we could of done with crashing out and watching TV for an hour! Internet was 11€ for 24hrs and wifi was hard to find in the city. The hotel is about 30 min from the city centre, 15 min walk to the subway and 2 trams to the city, the trains are every few minutes when you get there. It is close to the airport, again about 30 when you walk to Europa Fira and catch the 46 bus to the airport. There isnt much around the Travelodge hotel (and be warned the hotel location on their website and Google is slightly out!!) but if you go to the shopping centre, there is a classy Italian place near the cinema. A meal there was one of the highlights of our trip! Barcelona was great!! But on another visit we would probably stay somewhere else!

Reviews.Title: “Clean but poor service”
Reviews.Author: Traveller1756
Reviews.Content: Stayed here with some friends for two nights. It's quite a distance from the city centre and even the cab driver didn't know where it was as it's tucked away on an industrial estate. The rooms were usual Travelodge quality. Basic but clean. The staff were useless and very rude. We came back to the hotel on a Saturday night and asked to buy a coffee, only to be shouted at by the only member of staff on duty who obviously didn't like English people. He said he had better things to do than make coffee at that time of night, and that English expect too much. Also, steer clear of the breakfast as it was probably the worst food I've ever tasted!

Reviews.Title: “A - outstanding for the price (booked in advance)”
Reviews.Author: dlrpkris
Reviews.Content: We got this hotel as part of a package break at a FANTASTIC price. It worked out about €25 a night. Knowing the Travelodge brand from back home, we gathered that we were in safe hands and weren't wrong. It's everything you'd expect. The comfort of the room and welcome of our stay were both faultless. Although the check-in staff would've have clearly rather served us in Spanish or Catalan, they did all they could do to help in English - even help track down lost baggage on our behalf. If you don't mind adding 5mins onto your typical journey time from a hotel to the nearest transport link then this hotel is a really good find. It is served excellently by the local train lines that connect to the central Metro network. Very inexpensive too. Vending machine in the foyer offers inexpensive refreshments 24/4 and the petrol station next door (open until around 21:00 is another option too). A really friendly, comfortable and easy stay :)

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel, same standard as you would expect from a UK Travelodge”
Reviews.Author: Si_uk_says
Reviews.Content: Nice hotel, a bit out of the way but easy connections to public transport. We followed the instructions for the bus to ikea and to also grab breakfast at ikea to. We stayed in a family room, laminated floor, ok bed and sofa bed. All looked relatively new ANC bathroom was to a good standard. Not the best outlook from our room onto the industrial building next-door but that did not bother us as we spent all day seeing the sights. There were a few vending machines in the foyer and one took notes, which was handy to grab a quick snack late in the evening!

Reviews.Title: “Decent budget hotel”
Reviews.Author: aerotrav
Reviews.Content: We stayed there couple of times and never paid more than 30 euros for our room, so I think it is a good choice if you have some other priorities to spend your money in Barcelona. The hotel has a free underground parking, although it might be a bit difficult to get into your spot, if you have anything bigger than compact car. I find the family room that we had very spacious and comfortable. The bathroom was also spacious, clean and with good shower (and bath). Certainly ask for the room on east side of the hotel (same side as entrance, facing gas station), as otherwise you have a wall in 2 meters from you window. When I booked my room on travelodge site, the rate description said that it is a non-refundable rate. However, apparently the hotel only charges you during the check-in,so you may have a bit more flexibility,even if booking at sales prices.

Reviews.Title: “friendly and helpfull good brkfast”
Reviews.Author: aelwenna60
Reviews.Content: just come back from barcelona faab . liked the travelodge not far from station metro on an industrial park but ok caught taxis each day apprrox 20 euro which was ok as difficulty in walking all good friendly clean and comfy we asked for extra pillows no problem also asked for kettle and tea for room no problem definatly go back thankyou staff

Reviews.Title: “Cheap deal but with problems.”
Reviews.Author: Kangarucci
Reviews.Content: We, family of 2 adults and 2 teenagers, stayed in two rooms as we received a bargain. Due to a cancelled flight with Easyjet we arrived at 9:30am with 4 bags and 4 backpacks. We could not check in early as the hotel was full. You have an option of paying 20 euros for an early check in but not guaranteed check in until 2pm. It was not until we asked about leaving our bags at the hotel that I spotted a sign saying that it was not possible to leave bags. There wasn't any sympathy from the check in guy whose English was poor. (I don't recall seeing this on their website!) We had to drag our bags to the nearest shopping centre about 2-3km away and spend 5 hours there waiting for check in. It was so hot and humid. The rooms were basic but clean. The air con in one room worked a treat but the other would not remain on. The air con was controlled by the reception not individually in the room. I contacted recption at least 10 times for them to reset the air con. It drove me mad having to ask so often. It would either come on for 10mins or not at all. If getting a taxi from the airport to the hotel don't pay more than 20 euros and make sure that the meter is on. The guy told us it was 25euros as he drove off without giving us the option to get out. He did not have the meter on and had us in a trapped situation. Our experience with this Travelodge was disappointing especially with not allowing us to leave our luggage. The only positives that I have are that it was cheap and clean.

Reviews.Title: “Appaling- dont bother”
Reviews.Author: Jenny_A123
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for two nights, looking for a hotel on a budget, we trusted that Travelodge, being familiar in the UK would provide us with a reasonable room at a decent enough rate. How wrong we were! The Hotel is hard to find, located in a deserted industrial estate opposite what appears to be a long abandoned shopping centre or similar. I didnt feel safe at night and there was nothing around really in the way of amenities, restaurants etc. Its mainly a residential area, there was a distinct stench of drains in the whole area.It is well served by public transport but the info given by the hotel about where to get the bus or metro and which services was practically non existent, we were given a map which did not show the location of the hotel and told to navigate using a photocopies badly drawn plan. he hotel has the bog standard travelodge fixtures and fittings, TV etc. It advertises 'air conditioning' yet we were unable to control the temperature which rose and rose. The staff were typically unsympathetic and we had to telephone reception 10 times between 9pm and 2am while being told "is good temperature, there is no problem yes?" and we said no repeatedly... eventually we persuaded someone to visit our room and he admitted yes, there was no way the temperature was the advertised 21C. Unfortunately by this point my son who has autistic spectrum disorder( part of our reason for choosing travelodge, due to the familiarity of the room styles) was sobbing, rocking, had stripped to his underwear and was desperately trying to stay cool. We were relocated to another room but were all exhausted and were very very glad indeed when it was time to check out. The staff came and complained we had not vacated our room by 10am, I pointed out that we had no slept the night before and that the check out time was in fact 12pm. They seemed unsympathetic and said "you need to leave" I would not recommend anyone stay at this hotel

Reviews.Title: “Good price, poor service”
Reviews.Author: Bubers
Reviews.Content: The front desk was not very pleasant not to say rude. I had problems with getting into the room on 4th floor because of constant electronic key failure so I had to go down to reception every time I wanted to enter the room. I had to wait to move into the room for 20 minutes because of the key-lock failure while it was being repaired. The front desk wasnt helpful and always questioned that the key failure could be my fault!! Also they hardly could speak English.

Reviews.Title: “A good hotel at a great price”
Reviews.Author: Smiley_Becks
Reviews.Content: As previous reviewers have said the Travelodge does what it says on the tin, budget accommodation that is clean and well presented, you know what you are going to get! As other reviewers said it is out of the city but we quite enjoyed this element of it a feeling that you could get out of the hustle and bustle of Barcelona. The directions and map on the website were not completely accurate, NobbyClarke63 in his review gives a good description of the location and also how to travel around Barcelona from the hotel. We paid 20 Euro per room per night so was a much cheaper option for staying in the more well known parts of Barcelona, however if you just turn up the rack room rate is 110 Euro a night (not sure if its worth this much!). Breakfast was an additional extra but we found it cheaper to visit the Ikea for breakfast, a Mediterranean breakfast which consisted of a crusty bread roll, olive oil, tomato, ham and a coffee cost only 1 Euro - bargain!!! Overall we enjoyed our stay in Barcelona and would stay at this hotel again as it makes for a excellent base to see the city. We would recommend it to anyone who wants to save their money for the sights, attractions and restaurants of Barcelona.

Reviews.Title: “Price outweighs location, beware the annual allnight rave”
Reviews.Author: SandmanBournemouth
Reviews.Content: As has been said before the price is good. The hotel is standard travelodge, the location poor but the ease of travel using the metro and T10 tickets makes everything relatively easy to do, just be ready to stay out all day and evening until you're ready to return for bed. If coming in rrom Barcelona airport jump on a 46 bus and get off at Ikea, look for it or the tall red cylindrical Porto Fira hotel that Paul Merton stayed at. Barcelona is expensive to visit, high admission charges for nearly everything of interest except the parks and Las Ramblas. Note that the Wold Heritage site the Hospital Sant Pau is currently closed for refurbishment or like me you will have a hot wasted journey to find it. One word of warning - PICKPOCKETS - in 6 days we had 3 attempts made on us, twice on the tube, blocking the entrance to the train and pushing up behind and once in the park 'collecting for charity' and using a clipboard to hie one hand underneath. Fortunately thanks to all the posters on tripadvisor we were prepared, all was safely secreted away and nothing was taken. THANK YOU everyone on here it saved our holiday. We had trouble getting good food at a sensible price even away from the main areas. We did find a restaurant / cafe on Las Ramblas near the Liceu metro station called Bello Italy, one day we had paella another we had paste both extremly good, cooked fresh not reheated from frozen as pealla is in a lot of places with a good portion of fish and shellfish in it at a sensible price. I know it's Italian, owned by a spaniard, staffed by other nationalities looks small on the outside but has a big first floor. They work on the principle of good simple food, friendly service, sensibly priced and not fleecing the tourists, how I wish for a few more places like that the world over! On a final point which hasn't been covered elsewhere on the nights of 18th and 19th June this year the were 2 council approved allnight raves opposite the hotel and nobody got any sleep. I don't know what the dates are for 2011 but if anyone is looking to go this time of year they better check before booking as a holiday without sleep is not much fun. I am currently taking this up with Travelodge.

Reviews.Title: “Budget accomodation, good value for money.”
Reviews.Author: mangoandpineapple
Reviews.Content: RECOMMENDED, budget accomodation. We are a family of 5 (kids aged 13,11 and 4) and booked 2 rooms at 20 Euros each room for 3 nights. It's no frills, but if you are on a budget and just need a place to sleep, its perfect. We were out all day, so it suited us. LOCATION: It's not the best and not that inconvenient. It also feels safe at night. There is a main road called Avinguada de la Gran Via, this is where the Europa Fira station is located aswell as bus stops and a shopping centre called Gran Via 2 . There are shops, coffee shops, eateries and a good supermarket (carrefor) on the bottom floor. There is also an IKEA which is good for a breakfast. All located near to each other on this main road. Placa Espanya - we spent a couple of hours in Placa Espanya one evening its worth a look around, the first thing you will say when appearing out of the station is" WOW", the architecture is fantastic. We then walked it back to the hotel which took about half an hour. DIRECTIONS: If you are arriving at Girona airport with Ryanair and take the Barcelona bus in to the centre then leave the bus station near bus bay one and you will see the Metro station sign. This is ARC DE TRIOMF metro station, take metro RED LINE 1 for PLACA ESPANYA and then the FGC train to EUROPA FIRA station. Leave the station towards the right exit, once you appear at road level take the road ahead of you keeping the tall red building (Hotel Porta Fira) to your right, walk down this road and straight on at the roundabout you will also keep the big Porcelanosa building to your right. Carry on down the road then take your next left and after a few minutes the travelodge is on your right. Here's a google maps link http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&source=s_d&saddr=41.356324,2.125554&daddr=Avinguda+de+Juan+Carlos+I+to:Avinguda+de+Juan+Carlos+I+to:Carrera+de+la+Bot%C3%A0nica&hl=en&geocode=%3BFdIKdwId2W8gAA%3BFb4KdwId528gAA%3BFcH9dgIdaIwgAA&mra=dme&mrcr=0&mrsp=0&sz=16&via=1,2&sll=41.355165,2.128172&sspn=0.007763,0.019205&ie=UTF8&z=16 If you are arriving at Barcelona airport the airport bus drops passengers off at PLACA ESPANYA, from here just follow directions as above. GETTING AROUND: We bought a T10 ticket from the machines at the Metro station for Euros 7.85. This will give 10 journeys anywhere in the city and it can be passed on to each other. An example of how it can be used is we travelled on the train then a metro and then a bus and it all classed as 1 journey with a total journey time of 1 hour and 15 minutes and we passed it on to each other. So we used 5 journeys there and 5 journeys back. Not bad we travelled around Barcelona for 7.85. It can be used over the period of your stay. So yes Travelodge is Ok. Ignore the negative feedback. Enjoy Barcelona.

Reviews.Title: “Worst hotel ever”
Reviews.Author: onejhg
Reviews.Content: I was currently staying at the Travelodge Hospitalet in Spain for only one night, because it was absolutely the worst hospitality I have ever received anywhere. First when booking this hotel, like any hotel the check in stated it was at noon. Well the day of, when I arrived; check in was at 3:30pm and any time before that you would have to pay a 10 Euro fee for early check in. This was ridiculous and I was upset but what made it worst was the rudeness of the front desk. The young lady was discourteous, rude, and I found it very offensive to speak to her. To make matters worst that night I wanted to get out of there as soon as possible and needed a wake up call the next morning. That night there was a different person at the front desk who’s manners weren’t as atrocious as the employee from earlier in the day. I specifically asked for a 6am wake up call, and of course the next day I wake up at 6:30 without one. I begin to hurry out of there only to receive my now late wake up call at 7:13am. As I check out, low and behold the front desk who made the late wake up call was the same rude employee from the day before. I realized that now not only was she uncouth but vindictive? This is the worst hotel within the Barcelona area and I recommend turning around and never staying there unless you enjoy an uncomfortable, annoying and frustrating time.

Reviews.Title: “Barcelona on a budget - The price outweighs the location”
Reviews.Author: gravynchips
Reviews.Content: We decided to book this hotel despite some of the negative reviews on trip advisor and we are so glad that we did. My partner and I are both in our mid 30s and the purpose of our visit to Barcelona was sightseeing on a budget. So rather than stay in a hostel with a central location and the possibility of being in a shared room we opted for the Travelodge and its “out of town” location for 35 Euros a night. Getting there....the bus only costs 1,40EUR each!!! When you clear arrivals at the airport leave the building and turn right, you’ll see a bus stop 50 yards ahead. Catch the number 46 and tell the driver you want to go to Ikea. It takes around 15 minutes and from memory is the 4th stop after you leave the airport. You’ll see it coming though as it’s big and blue like the ones we have over here. I’ve uploaded an aerial picture with the route you need to take once you’re off the bus, it’s about a 10 minute walk with luggage. To get back to the airport, the same bus takes you from a stop exactly opposite. The Hotel & Room.... clean and comfy Check-in was quick and friendly and all the staff spoke good English. The hotel must have been fairly quiet as they gave us a family room which was huge with a double bed, large sofabed, big wardrobe, desk with chair and large bathroom with a great power shower. We had maid service every day where they changed the bedding and towels and cleaned the floors and bathroom. Previous reviews have stated that there is noise from the 24 hour garage next to the hotel, we can confirm that the garage is no longer open at night and we didn’t have any issues with noise. We had a TV in our room and the only English channel it showed was CNN, which was helpful for keeping up to date on the impending ash cloud. We didn’t pay for the breakfast option at the hotel so we stopped at the Gran Via 2 shopping centre on our way to the metro each day. The centre is full of restaurants, cafes and shops like Zara, H&M, sports shops etc. There’s also a large Carrefour supermarket. Getting into town......The Metro The metro is the easiest way to get around Barcelona as it’s quick and simple to navigate. The nearest station is Europa Fira which is in between Ikea and the Gran Via 2 shopping centre. We bought a T-10 ticket from the machine at the station which gives you 10 journeys on the metro, bus and train for 7,85EUR. It’s also worth knowing that you can change lines as many times as you like within 75 minutes and it only counts as one trip. Once through the barrier take the stairs to your left and wait for the next train. All trains on this line terminate at Placa Espanya so you don’t have to worry about getting on the right train. Once off, you can either exit at Placa Espanya and go to Mont Juic and see the fountains, galleries and Olympic stadium or head for L1 and get on the train to Placa de Catalunya which is right in the centre of town. If you want to go to the marina (Port Vell) then head for L3 and get off at Drassanes. To get back to Europa Fira just use the same lines but the platforms on the opposite side from where you got off earlier. Simple. The whole journey from the hotel to the centre of town takes around 20 minutes; the walk to the metro takes 10 minutes, you only have to wait around 3 minutes for the next train and the journey to Placa Espanya takes 4 minutes. A quick line change and another 3 minute train journey to Placa Catalunya and you’re looking down La Rambla. Conclusion.... The hotel is in a business district and there is some building work going on up near the metro but it has no noise effect on the hotel. There are a lot of other hotels nearby so it’s not deserted after dark as other reviews would suggest. We were getting off the metro at around midnight each night and there were always scores of other people getting off with us and heading off to the various hotels. We never felt unsafe or isolated at anytime we were there. Barcelona is a wonderful city but it does suffer from pickpockets. It only happens in the tourist areas and in the main Metro stations, just be sure to keep you bags zipped and wallets and phones in your front pockets. Beware of anyone asking for directions holding a map, groups of young children with clipboards, someone telling you you’ve got bird poo on your back or just any sort of attention diversion. Remove rucksacks from your back when standing on the main Metro stations and you’ll be fine. We stayed 4 nights at a total cost of £126GBP, the average price of a hotel around centre of Barcelona is £100GBP per night, we used 2 T-10 between us at a cost of £12GBP so if you don’t mind a bit of walking and you want more money in your pocket to spend on the rather expensive restaurants and bars of Barcelona then this hotel is a no brainer, we’ll definitely use it the next time we visit.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Value For Money”
Reviews.Author: Family091
Reviews.Content: On our arrival at the Hotel the receptionists was extremely helpful, the hotel is on an industrial estate and we did worry that we may have made a mistake, but am pleased to report we didn't. Hotel is within 5-15 mins walk for the Bus stop which take you straight into Barcelona, the Metro and a lovely Shopping complex Gran Via 2 which has some nice restaurants to eat in the evenings when returning from a busy day sightseeing in Barcelona. The bus journey takes about 15-20 mins and is so just so simple and cheap to use we didn't bother with the metro. Hotel is spotless, breakfast was worth the 7Euros eat as much as you like. Overall found this hotel excellent value for money if you don't mind a little commuting, will definately book this hotel when we return. One other TIP there is a bus Number 46 that runs to and from the Airport if you can get this to transfer I would recommend it we caught a Taxi out to the Hotel when we arrived which cost us 26Euros, we caught the bus on our return to the airport 4.20Euros.

Reviews.Title: “A great Place to stay. Excellent Price and Service but beware of Website”
Reviews.Author: Montrealeronthemove
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Travelodge l'hospitalet before and after a 21-day Mediterranean Cruise. We were 6 days in Barcelona before the cruise and 3 days after. The hotel is located about 5 minutes by bus from Plaza Espanya. It is in the "Fira" (Fair) area of barcelona. We came to the hotel from the airport and we travelled with the local bus # 46 which leaves you directly in front of the IKEA store. You then have a 7-to 8-minute walk to get to the hotel. When we got there we were very well treated by the staff at the reception desk. Since we had a flight from Canada, we were there earlier than check in time (3 p.m.) and we were given a room almost right away (around 12). There is no guarantee of this, but the hotel staff is very helpful and will go the extra mile to satisfy their customers. We had encountered huge problem with the website (managed in England) which by the way has a extremely bad customer service, but the hotel staff in Barcelona was absolutely great. The hotel is fairly new and the rooms are spacious. (See photos). The hotel is in a quiet area because of its location in an industrial park. At night there is no noise except for the adjoining gas station and normally no noise after 10 or 11 pm. In the morning two types of breakfast are available for a fee: Full buffet or continental. The first floor has the reception area, the breakfast area, an internet station (fee) and a few sofas and chairs. There are also vending machines on prem, plus you can buy hot beverages from the reception. A big shopping mall (Fira Gran Via) is located about 5 to10 minutes walk from the hotel and there you will find many restaurants with a variety of menus for all tastes. The train station is located also about 5 minutes away walking and will take you directly to Plaza Espanya where you can connect to the Metro system. A couple of buses also go by Gran Via (near train station and IKEA) like number 46 and 65 for those who prefer to see the beautiful architecture of Barcelona. These buses will also take you to Plaza Espanya. A bus stops almost in front of the hotel ( number 72) but it does not link to a specific subway station and goes in residential district more than places where tourists have interest to go to. We really enjoyed our stay at this hotel where the staff is friendly, helpful and give the extra mile to make their customers happy. Prices at this hotel when reserved via their website can be as low as 35 Euros or approx. 50 Canadian or US Dollars. Just be aware that the website is very badly set and that, should you have a problem with a reservation (like it happened with some of ours), the customer service in England is absolutely putrid and it takes weeks to get a very small problem settled. Travelodge UK has a lot of work to do in that respect. Also know that when booking many consecutive nights, you have to reserve them one by one to be able to get the best price quoted. It makes very little sense but it follows the pattern mentioned above: "no customer service". By the way should the reservation system do a "time out" on your reservation before full completion but after giving the credit card number, make sure to check your email (given for confirmation) before going and booking again. You may find yourself with 2 bookings and no-one to help you correct the situation. Travelodge (England) will tell you that their system makes no errors. Travelodge UK doesn't make the effort to have one person settle a discrepancy since you can never have the same agent answer your request and they have the lowest customer service I have ever seen. The staff of the hotel in Barcelona though is absolutely great, the rooms are comfortable and the price is the best value considering the closeness to center and services around. Thank you to the hotel staff: Marina, Jonatan and Juan Cruz who succeeded in making our stay very enjoyable.

Reviews.Title: “Clean and good value but location not the best”
Reviews.Author: judithO
Reviews.Content: This hotel was up to Travelodge's usual spotless standard. I had to request a kettle etc for the room. There was no problem is getting this from the desk. The hotel is rather out of the way and I would not have found it if I hadn't checked on the Trip advisor forum. I stayed one night before a cruise so the location was Ok for me.

Reviews.Title: “Never think about it”
Reviews.Author: gosalyn
Reviews.Content: Far away from the city center. It takes you 15-20 min. to reach the nearest subway. The air conditioning blows smoking allowed room's smell inside your room if you stay in the same floor with the smokers. Breakfast is very poor and the stuff is rude. The only thing is, it's clean enough. But that's all.

Reviews.Title: “I would not recommend this hotel to solo travellers without a car”
Reviews.Author: LondonDmgirl
Reviews.Content: I had a very bad experience at this hotel and it nearly spoiled my holiday. I would not recommend this hotel to solo travellers ( especially when a lady or even a group of girlfriends it is NOT safe to walk around this area after 8 pm ) or anyone that cannot speak spanish or catalan. The room : apart from the cleanliness it is very basic and far from 3 star hotel standards.I was given a room next to the elevator and it was so noisy at night I could hardly sleep, even exhausted after one busy day. Pointless to ask for kettle facilities at the reception, you wont even get a spoon or sugar, then the next day the chambermaid will take the cup and tea/coffee left without replacing it. I had a very disturbing and unsafe experience on the second night, due to a guy next door shouting for half an hour in spanish at 4 am.Thats when you understand why every room is equiped with a bull's eye and how useful it is. Then the guy was trying to smash in next room's door with a chair and I called reception staff for help. Needless to say I had to explain all of this in english. Noise suddently stopped and guys disappeared in their room.The guy from the reception came to have a quick look, but did absolutely nothing to reassure or secure me.He didnt tell them anything or investigate further .... !!!!! I felt very unsafe at this hotel, I have travelled a lot as a solo traveller through Europe and have never experienced such a bad thing in hotels. Now the location : lost in the middle of an industrial zone, once again forget it if you are without a car, or a single lady wishing to come back after 9 pm or you'll be in serious trouble, plus it is not a 5 minute walk to the underground or the buses but rather a 15 minute one.I've tried every shortcut, I never made it in 5 minutes.Dont believe what the positive reviews say.There's a lot of traffic and it is not safe or pleasant walking around, there is not a soul around, just building construction work, anything can happen. I had trouble on my way back with men stopping their car, and I guess the main purpose was not for assistance, even if i dont speak a word of spanish, Allow 45 minutes to reach the city center from the hotel, which is quite a waste of time considering the number of 2 star hotels with better service or safety you may book inside Barcelona.I will defo not recomment this hotel to anyone or go back to any travelodge, but you may be luckier.

Reviews.Title: “Great basic hotel!”
Reviews.Author: tresvatos
Reviews.Content: Basic Basic Room, but NICE staff, and housekeeping ( I speak fluent Spanish Though), so it was no trouble communicating.. It is away from the city attraction, but metro is 5 minute walk... I give it an A..

Reviews.Title: “Good Value & Location - even with a car”
Reviews.Author: BritishBlueCat
Reviews.Content: Having spent 2 weeks in the South of Spain we needed some over night stops for our drive back to the UK having driven in our own car from Calais. The only requirement my husband insists on when i choose hotels when we are travelling in our own car is safe car parking and Internet accesses for the laptop & Iphones, both of which we had free of charge at the Travelodge. Having pre-booked on the UK web-site we got the room for 35euros, a steal at that price. It was easy to find in the car, although we did use Sat Nav and i had used google street maps to see what it looked like, it was still easy to drive to when you think Barcelona is a busy city. Its location is within a retail park area, with large modern hotels used for conferences at the near-by exhibition hall. We where able to park the car free of charge in an underground car park which was excellent as it was full of our personal belongings. We arrived about 5.30pm and once we had stored our belongings we ventured into Barcelona. Having been many times before we just wanted to pop down to Las Ramblas & find somewhere to eat for the evening. The reception desk gave us a map and directed us to the nearest metro station which was a brisk 5-10 min walk. The area goes very quiet on an evening as the shops have closed and there is very little traffic, we felt safe walking around and the metro station was very clean and modern compared to London. It was quick, cheap and a lot of fun catching the tube into the centre of Barcelona, you need to change once onto a different line. We both agreed that if ever came again and flew in for a mini weekend we would stay at the Travelodge based on price, its easy to catch public transport and explore and leaves you to spend your money on nice meals & sightseeing. The room was clean and just like UK Travelodges, basic but served a purpose. We had a good nights sleep, a refreshing shower and use of a kettle which we used to top up our own flasks for the next days journey. We did not have breakfast as we had our own travel fridge & picnic hamper with us, otherwise we would have ventured out and picked something up. Good value for money, what you would expect from a modern Travelodg

Reviews.Title: “A cheap hotel, ideal for our holiday.”
Reviews.Author: redlaura4185
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I have just returned from the Travelodge Barcelona. We wanted a cheap hotel, I recommend booking in advance- we got our room for 45euro a night instead of the 119euro if you were to just turn up. We really enjoyed our stay there as it suited our needs perfectly. I was a bit reticent about staying in a Travelodge in a foreign country because I didn't know what to expect. However, my concerns were unwarranted. This one was perfect. It was immacutely clean, modern and the beds comfortable. If you were to stay more than one night, cleaners do come in and change the sheets and towels. We went in november so didn't need the Air Con- so I don't know if they would charge for that as most hotels do. Tea making facilities were available- I did have to ask for it, but that is no problem. Also, there was a colour TV in the room that only picked up CNN, again not a problem because we were hardly there and just used the hotel for a shower and to sleep- like all Travelodges really. The hotel is located on a busy main road, next to a BP garage- perfect for getting bottles of water at a cheap price. Opening hours are between 8am-10pm- so no "busy car wash to keep you awake" as reported in another review. Before we went we bought a Barcelona Card- which I recommend. The 30euro price tag for 3 days was worth the money, but only if your stay heavily relies on using the metro, train or bus. Ours' did so it made things much easier to get around the city. The metro is clean and friendly- unlike the London tube. As for things to do while you are in the city you really are spoilt for choice- I would advise doing a bus tour- you are taken directly to the attractions and it is very nice to sit and relax and to take the pressure off your very tired feet! Each tour takes 2 and a half hours and you can hop on and off whenever you want to. The tour comopany does not encourage you to do both tours- but we did and saved 25euros. I would recommend the Travelodge to others as it is cheap and clean. It's just like any other in this country and perfect for a mini-break away.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place & Fantasic Service”
Reviews.Author: Sealyspeak
Reviews.Content: At €35 a night you could not complain really. The key to this hotel is understanding the location to everything. €20 to and from the airport in a taxi. The hotel seems a little out the way, but it is €12 approx to town, which is fine now and again, but a waste of money if done too often. The metro stop is EUROPA FIRA which is 5 mins away from the hotel (the staff will tell you this), don't confuse it with the Fira Barcelona conference center as I did! Get a T10 ticket, Zone 1 for €7.70 and it will last 10 journeys. Your first stop is to Espanya (platform 2, and is the only stop ANY train will go to in this direction as it is the end of the line). Once there, Barcelona is your lobster. The breakfast is fine now and again, you can check it out before you buy anyway. It is very near Gran Via 2 which is a modern shopping place with places to eat and very handy for everything. But the key is to get your head around the tube which is very easy and a little extra adventure to your break. Maria? at the desk was a complete star and deserves a mention. She helped us many times! Look forward to staying there again, Barcelona is fantastic, don't be afraid of getting lost! The football fans might want to know that McCarthys Irish bar has Prem football on weekends and the pizza place RIGHT next door is AMAZING. Cant remember the street, but it is just off the Gothic Cathedral.

Reviews.Title: “Good Hotel to use as a base to see Barcelona”
Reviews.Author: highguyuk
Reviews.Content: I booked this Hotel through a Travelodge Sale, and managed to secure 5 nights for 10Euros per night which I was very happy with. My Partner and I attended in the first week of September. After arriving from Barcelona Airport, we caught the Aerobus to Gran Via – which we thought was the nearby shopping centre – and then as it turned out we were in the wrong place we got a taxi to the Hotel. Total cost around 20 Euros, so cheaper than getting a Taxi from the Airport and maybe something to be looked into. Make sure you have the address of the Hotel on you if you need a Taxi, our driver didn’t know where to go until I pointed out that there was a BP Garage opposite. We arrived approx 9pm. Check-in takes a couple of minutes, and they asked for our passports as proof of identity. Don’t forget to ask for a Kettle, which they happily supplied although without milk. The room was a typical Travelodge, although spacious as we had booked the Family Room. We had quite a good view looking onto the Olympic Stadium in the distance. However, this has a negative side as you also face onto the BP Garage which has possibly the busiest car wash in Spain on it. Cars were being washed throughout the night, and traffic started to build up from 7am onwards. On the other hand, if your room faced the other way all you would see is the building opposite but it would be quieter, all depends on what you might prefer. The room has Air Conditioning, although we are not sure if ours was working as it was quite hot! We opened the windows the first few nights, but be warned we were bitten a lot. Take precautions with you. Room had a TV with approx 12-15 Spanish TV Channels, we ended up watching CNN American News whenever we wanted the TV on. Room was clean, Bathroom too with Towels and Soap provided. The Hotel is to be used as a base. It needs to be used as somewhere to sleep, and plan your days so that you won’t return back to the Hotel until you won’t want to leave it again that day. It is set in a commercial area, which when walking between the Hotel and the Metro is very deserted. It is a fair walk to either of the Metro Stations (Ildefons Cerda or Europa Fira). We reckoned IIdefons Cerda is the quicker, but Europa Fira is the nicer/easier walk. The Metro is very simple to use, very easy. As mentioned in other reviews, purchase your T-10 tickets from the machine at the metro station and off you go. There is no need to purchase individual tickets for people either, just buy one T-10 at a time and use that until it has run out between you all and get another one. There is advice on the internet about this. Saves you potentially wasting Journeys. If you can, print off a Metro Map before you go as it is much easier that way. For those hiring a car, there is car parking available around the Hotel. You don't need to worry about not having enough spaces. There is the large shopping Centre, Gran Via 2, very close to the IIdefons Cerda Metro Station. This has everything you could need in it. The Carrefour Food Shopping is on the ground floor, and there is a multitude of shops and cafes in there. We had lunch 1 day at the Carrefour Café which was very reasonably priced and quite good. There is an Ikea close by too which you could use for Breakfast, if you ask reception they can point you in the right direction. Unfortunately, we were not able to sample the Breakfast as when we went it turn out to be a “Catalan Fiesta Day” so it was closes – as was most of Barcelona. (Just spend 2 minutes checking when these Spanish Bank Holidays are. EVERYTHING except cafes and bars were closed) We checked out early to make our way back to the Airport. We left and travelled to Europa Fira, and from there onto the next station Gornal where we caught the RENFE train from back to the Airport. Very, very simple. At Gornal you do need to leave the station and walk over to the next station but it is all sign posted. If we had known it was so easy, we would have used this service on our arrival to Barcelona. We would definitely use the Hotel again if we visited Barcelona. Unless you travel outside of Barcelona, I think you can see the majority of it in 4/5 days so we won’t visit Barcelona again for quite a few years. Just remember that it’s a Hotel to use as somewhere great to sleep, but have your days out planned in advance.

Reviews.Title: “Very good value and friendly service”
Reviews.Author: kmatth
Reviews.Content: A clean, basic and friendly hotel that is a little out of the way. It cost us 25 euros from the airport and only 20 on our return, alternatively buses were available. The hotel is situated quite a way from catalunya which is pretty much Barcelona city centre. To get there we had a ten minute walk to the metro-station and had to get 2 metro's to get to our destination, in all it takes around 25 minutes. The metro is very efficient though, if you are planning to go you get on the metro at Europa- Fira to Espanya, then take a seperate metro from Espanya to Catalunya. Also, purchase a t-10 that allows 10 trips under 15 minutes and is 7.70 euros at the turnstiles. The room was very clean, but did not include basic utensils such as a kettle or fridge so be weary. Also, breakfast is available from 7.50 euro but only consists of croissant, cheese and ham, coffee and orange juice, white bread and some bits of bacon, egg and sausage which were very fatty and small in quantity. A better quality breakfast can be purchased in the centre itself. All in all, for the price we paid it was very good value!

Reviews.Title: “Great value as always!”
Reviews.Author: ninabean
Reviews.Content: Yes its quite a hike into the centre of Barcelona but at 20 euros a night in the height of summer we could not complain! We did forget our driving licence/passport so we did have a few problems checking in but the manager was very accomodating and after an hour we did manage an early check in. The room was clean, modern, basic but just the job. The location was only a 10min taxi ride from Playa Catalunya. We opted for taxis as there were 4 of us and in the heat it just wasnt worth the hassle of busses/tube etc. The cost was usually between 9 and 13 euros. We didnt stay for breakfast as we wanted an early stary and went straight to Sagrada and picked up some pastries there. Would defo stay there again if on a budget

Reviews.Title: “Great value hotel, little out of the way though!”
Reviews.Author: SallyCC
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for 3 nights, around 30 Euros a night, so we considered this to be good value for money. The hotel is out of the centre and public transport is needed to reach anywhere of interest, but we found the Metro very efficient and used it loads. The nearest metro is a 10-15 minute walk from the hotel, and is then 3 stops from Placa Espana, which connects via another metro line to Placa Cataluna the main hub/square, near the Ramblas. Friendly staff, always willing to assist with requests for tea bags, kettles and also great for directions. It was extremely hot whilst we were there, and we stocked up with water etc from the BP petrol station next door, as it was loads cheaper than the Travelodge vending machines. We did not drink or eat at the Travelodge, so cannot comment on the food there, or the breakfast quality. All in all a good quality basic hotel, clean room and pretty quiet at night, but be prepared for plenty of walking to and from public transport departure points!

Reviews.Title: “Good value, and conveniently located”
Reviews.Author: The_Lang
Reviews.Content: Me, my wife and our three year old daughter have just returned from a long weekend break in Barcelona, staying 3 nights at the travelodge. We chose it as you always know what you get with Travelodge and the rooms were €45 per night. Hotel was fine, as expected, and the staff pleasant. We took the Barcelona bus from Gerona airport (€21 return for two adults, under 4's are free) and it was a lovely ride into the Estacio Nord (approximately 1 hour 15 minutes). We then took a taxi to the hotel at a cost of €20. If we went again on our own we would just make the two minute walk to the Arc de Triompf Metro station, where you can catch the L1 line to Placa Espanya (we did this on the way back to the station, although there are quite a lot of steps in the Arc de Triompf station) The hotel, I would say was situated in a commercial area, rather than industrial, as the area around the hotel towards the Gran Via 2 shopping complex was well designed, and our daughter loved running along all of the walls and stone benches. We didn't arrive at the hotel until after 8pm, so were looking for somewhere close to eat. If you turn left out of the hotel, then right at the first roundabout you come to and follow that road round (past the aforementioned walls and benches) alongside the Gran Via exhibition centre, you will see the Gran Via 2 shopping centre and cinema on your right (no more than a 10 minute walk for an adult (kids can, and do make it longer!). At the Gran Via 2 there are plenty of restaurants, a kids fair, a delicious ice cream shop, cinema and the shopping mall. If you turn right out of the hotel, and cross over the road, turn left up the first road you come to (which takes you under a strange tunnel like structure connecting two buidlings) and carry on walking, you will pass the Gran Via 2 on your left hand side. Carry on up past this and you will arrive at the main road (very easy to cross). Cross over this and you are at the Ildefons Cerda metro station on the L8 line (you can take the lift down to the station). We did this walk a number of times, with a pushchair and it took no more than 15 minutes (but then who's in a rush when you're away from home?) The Metro is brilliant and we never waited for more than 3.5 minutes for any train. Buy a T-10 ticket at the ticket machines (easy to use and with English translation). You can use the ticket between you (rather than having to buy one each), just place it in the ticket barriers, collect it, and proceed through (if more than one of you just put it back through each time). From this station you will need to go two stops to Place Espanya, from where the rest of Barcelona is your oyster. My tips on where to go would be: 1. Park Guell - quite an experience to walk up to this park (especially the escaltors in the street). We managed it with a pushchair, which was hard work, but the views from the top of the Tower of the Three Crosses are absolutely breathtaking and made it all worth the effort. You can then walk down to the Gaudi Museum and sit on the worlds longest bench. 2. Sagrada Familia - the icon landmark of Barcelona, and one of the strangest buildings you will ever see. You can pay €11 to walk to the top of one of the towers, but you get better views from Park Guell, and you can see the Sagrada Familia well enough from outside 3. Magic Fountains - this is on Thu to Sun (in the summer) every half hour from 9 pm to 11pm in Montjuic Park. It is basically a giant fountain which dances with music and lights. It gets very busy, so try and get there early (we arrived at 8:30 and got a got spot) to enjoy the spectacular. 4. Montjuic Castle - You can catch the funicular from the Par-llel stop on the L3 line, up to the cable car which takes you up to the castle (€16 per adult, but worth it). Again the views are spectacular, but from the complete opposite side of Barcelona from Park Guell. 5. Barcelona beach and harbour - We spent half a day round here (mainly to keep our daughter happy) but the beaches are beautiful (try and take your own towels rather than hiring a sunbed, as they wanted to charge us €15 for 2 beds and an umbrella at 2 in the afternoon). The harbour is picturesque, and there is some fantastic architecture all around. Overall, we all had a brilliant time, and the hotel was a convenient base. We will definately be coming back to Barcelona, and would probably stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Isolated - but a comfortable stay”
Reviews.Author: babyjenz
Reviews.Content: I got this hotel as part of a holiday package deal and though it's rather isolated in more of an industrial part of the city, the hotel itself is a great place to stay. Having gone in early August, the temperatures outside were humid and reaching up to 37 degrees, and it was an absolute relief to walk through the doors of the hotel, to lovely cooled temperatures via aircon, in both the reception and our room. The reception staff are friendly, spoke good English, and were very helpful when we needed directions. It's about a 15 minute walk to the nearest bus stop (if you're coming from the airport) and the tube station, and about a 5-10 minute walk to Gran Via, a shopping complex with great food options and even a cinema. My main tip would be if you're going in summer, be sure to get yourself a bottle of water as often as you can from the BP next door to travelodge - with the walk to the tube etc, you will definitely need it!

Reviews.Title: “Low budget but do-able if you aren't fussy”
Reviews.Author: livinginnasuitcase
Reviews.Content: Had to book a hotel in Barcelona after our Couchsurfer host cancelled at the last minute, myself and my 2 teenage kids travelling on a bit of a budget so this option seemed the least painful :) It was ordinary accomodation, nothing special although it was clean and reliable. We paid for internet access (more than we paid in any other hotel we stayed at, including Paris) and it was slow to the point of only being able to load 1 page at a time on a new laptop. The hotel is out of town, in a semi-industrial part of the suburbs, but there is a metro station less than 5 minutes walk away which gets you to the city centre in about 20 minutes. Yes you can use the busses as recommended by another reviewer here, but we found the metro easier. Buy a T10 ticket at the station from the auto machine, you can use them for more than 1 person at a time (first person goes through gate, passes ticket back to 2nd person, 2 trips are recorded on the ticket), best way to get around even if you have a car (which we did). Its a short walk to a large shopping centre complex, and we brought food back to our room for breakfasts etc, as the breakfast prices at the hotel were astronomical for what was offered. We asked for a kettle & cups etc and they were provided without fuss. Whoever wrote the review about the car park being too small - yes it is small, but I got our hired Peugeot in there no probs, and even if that was a problem there was also parking out the front on the street. Oh and they charge for the underground parking as well.

Reviews.Title: “Overpriced, grubby business hotel”
Reviews.Author: swissmiss2009
Reviews.Content: I would not recommend this hotel to anyone on any budget, despite its proximity to the fairgrounds. The walls were covered with marks from suitcases, there was sandy debris on the bathroom floor, and to top it all off a squashed mosquito with a shoeprint on the ceiling above the bed. There is no bar or restaurant, just a vending machine in the lobby. At nearly 120 Euro a night, this hotel was way overpriced. Business travellers are better of staying downtown and paying a few Euros for a taxi back to the congress halls.

Reviews.Title: “Bus runs right by hotel”
Reviews.Author: Avalon123
Reviews.Content: I have just returned from a visit to this hotel. I read the previous reviews and found a lot of useful information regarding getting to the hotel by bus or metro and then walking to the hotel from the buses outside Ikea, or Gran Via 2 Shopping Centre or the Europa Fira metro station. However, on the evening before the last full day of my visit I noticed a bus going up and down C/Botanica and asked the receptionist about it. The bus is the 72 and you can get to the Place Espanya as follows, without the longish walk (it rained all three days I was there): Walk out of the hotel and go past the BP garage next door, cross over the side road next to the BP Garage and the bus stop is right in front of you, less than 1 minute from the hotel and on the same road. Catch the 72 and go for four stops. Get off at a stop on the liong road Pg de la Zona France. At the same stop you get off at, you can then catch either a 109, 37 or 9 bus. They are very frequent. Any of these buses will take you to the Place Espana where you are well placed to catch the metro or get on the Bus Turistic to anywhere in the centre of Barcelona. The whole journey, including any ongoing travel on the metro, will be considered as one trip with your T10 ticket (7 Euros 70 for 10 complete journeys). To go back to the hotel, just cross the road on Place Espanya from where you got off the bus and catch the 109, 37 or 9 back to one of the stops on the Pg de la Zona Franca and then get the 72 which will stop right opposite the Travelodge. It was much easier than I thought it was going to be. You can pick up the 72 at all the stops along the Pg de la Zona Franca. Just look at the top of the bus stops and you will see the number on there. The only thing to watch out for, when you are in the Place Espanya, don't get mislead by the L72, that is a completely different service. Stick to getting the 108, 37 or 9. I hope this information is helpful. A busmap from any of the information centres is quite useful. As regards the Travelodge, it is very good value (I paid 30 Euros for 3 nights on the £10/10 Euros a night special offer that Travelodge runs from time to time.) It is clean, fairly new. but otherwise just like British Travelodges. Ask at Reception for a kettle, cups, teabags. They will also give you a wine glass of milk for your tea. We also asked the chambermaid for extra pillows and she put them in the room straight away. The Chinese buffet at the restaurant near the Gran Via 2 (see an earlier review) was very good value. All in all, if I had found out about the bus from outside the hotel sooner, I would have enjoyed my wet stay in Barcelona more.

Reviews.Title: “A good Value stay!”
Reviews.Author: kerryrough
Reviews.Content: I booked flights from East Midlands to Girona for around £45. From Girona airport there is a bus terminal outside where you can get a bus to the Estacio Nord in Barcelona for 21 Euros return. Getting to the travelodge is a bit trickier! It is around a 35-45 minute journey from the Estacio Nord and around 30-40 minutes from the Playa de Catalunya (Main central part). Outside the Estacio Nord catch a metro (Line 1 RED) from Arc De Triomf (Outside the bus station) to Playa de Catalunya, only two stops away. At the Playa de Catalunya (extremely busy!) cross the road to find a few busstops. We caught the L95 (you can also get the L94) bus. All travel (Metro, Bus, Train) is 1 Euro 35 for each trip. We then took the L95 outside of the central part of the city (past Playa Espanya) to Gran Via. unfortunately the roads fall outside of normal maps! However there are several other ways of getting to the hotel from the centre, but this was the easiest and also offered a better view than the train! You then leave the bus opposite Gran Via 2 Shopping Centre, it has huge blue neon letters and is around 10 minutes away- depending on traffic! There are lots of buildings and its mostly industrial. Ok so getting off the bus the best thing to do is cross the main road (so you are outside the Gran Via 2 shopping centre) and then walk down a diagonal road (2 tall office block buildings on the right) and you should find yourself outside a huge exhibition centre that is white. Hopefully this makes some sense! Walk around this building to the left and you will pass the Hotel Prestige Congress on the right. Turn left and the Travelodge is on the other side of the road! It was a bit confusing to find, but you are honestly no more than 10 minutes walk from the busstop! Places to eat are few and far between at the travelodge, however at the Gran Via 2 shopping centre, outside there is a Chinese restaurant, Burger Restaurant and a few Tapas restaurants that are reasonable to eat at. (Baskonia-Orange and Brown is wuite good). Getting into town is easy, take a bus from the busstop outside the Gran Via 2 and you can get off at Playa de Catalunya. Best things to spend your money on:- Olympic Stadium is worth seeing as its free and the museum was only 4 Euros. Sagrada Familia costs 11 Euros to get in (Adult) however what they don't teel you is that you have to queue for the lift to take you up (60 mins!) and costs an extra 2.50! Menu del dia is the way forward as you can get a lot for your money. There is a beautiful restaurant called TallerdeTapas hidden away in the Gothic quarter- walk down the Ramblas towards the sea, halfway down is a Mcdonalds and KFC. Turn left there and walk down some alleyways around there and explore that area, right next to a church is this great Tapas place. Me and my boyfriend ended up spending a lot of money on things we didn't need to. sit inside for drinks, there is a massive premium for sitting outside! Drinks on top of the menu del dia hike up the prices (3 Euros for a can of coke in 1 place!) Look around don't head into the first place you see, it's worth it! Check out the Olympic Port and the Parc Guell if it's good weather as its free. We tended to stay out all day so don't worry about getting up really early as you will just exhaust yourself- we left around 10.30am each day and by the time you have donw everything in one day you will be tired! The Spaniards also tend to leave things late, so by waking up later on we didn't need a breakfast (thought the travelodge does have this at a cost of 7 Euros) and then have menu del dia for Lunch (2-4pm) and then have a late dinner. If you are heading out for dinner at 6pm everywhere will be dead and there will be a lack of atmosphere! Get a t-10 travel card at any of the metro machines as this only costs 7 Euros 70 and will save you on journeys. The marketplace off the Ramblas if really good to walk around, however bee vigilant as it gets crowded and we all know what can happen if we aren't watching our bags! Anyway, was a really good trip- three whole days was enough after all the walking around- Barcelona is really spread out so be prepared to do a bit of walking to see things though the transport system is really good!

Reviews.Title: “ideal for a base...”
Reviews.Author: DIDDLY-35
Reviews.Content: Booked the travelodge basically beacuse it was only 20 euros a night did this by booking the nights individually on the travelodge website if you did a block booking the rooms were coming up at 45 euros per night. Found the instructions and directions provided by previous reviewers invaluable ! only slight hitch was that we were unsure where too catch the 46 bus at the airport..you have to turn right out of the terminal and you will see lots of buses DO NOT get on any bus that says A1 YOU NEED THE RED 46 BUS it costs 1euro 35 and stops right outside IKEA.about 20 minute journey then follow the directions provided by earlier reviews. Might be a good idea to go into to IKEA for coffee food etc as it is not cheap in the Travelodge about 2 ero 50 for beer and 2 euro for coffee although never ate in the Tavelodge we used Ikea every morning coffee and croissiant/muffin/ or toast 1 euro from 9-11 lunch not served till 12 but sandwhiches from 11 for about 2 euro. The travelodge is on a business estate and very little around but, very clean and felt safe walking from metro each night. We just used this as a base..it was very clean but basic slightly warm as air conditioning not the best. The walk from the metro is about 15 mins and is the L8 line which is so new probably not in your guide book. Just catch the L8 to |Espanya and then you can pick up other lines... Placa d Catalunya on the L1 line to Fondo takes you to the la Ramblas. i would recommend you but a T10 ticket at the metro station..they cost 7euros and usable on any metro in zone 1 (which basically covers the whole city) and also the buses around the city and to and from the Airport. It took us two metros to get to la ramblas and this is classed as one Journey as long as taken within 1he 15 mins. I would not recommend this hotel for famillees with children unless you have a car as there is nothing at the hotel and nowhere that close to walk at night for dinner etc.
